node.text:
Over the last nine years, Jose Castillo @josecastillo911 has taught GSD students in studios and courses examining housing and infrastructure in Mexico. In this video, Castillo reflects on his pedagogy, with a focus on his fall 2019 studio "Beyond the Mayan Train: Housing & Infrastructure in Yucatán." Jimena David Garza (MUP '20) and Saeb Ali Khan @saebkhan (MAUD '20) also share perspectives on the student experience. Watch the full faculty mini-course at youtube.com/TheHarvardGSD⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
This important work would not be possible without the generosity of our alumni and friends. Your gift provides immediate support to the future of design education. Give today at 🔗hgsd.us/giving20⁣⁣⁣⁣
--⁣⁣⁣⁣
#HarvardGSD #Architecture #UrbanPlanning #UrbanDesign #Housing

node.title: Learning in action 🎥 Housing in Mexico: A Multi-Year Exploration

node.text:
Coastal regions around the world are increasingly impacted by sea level rise, and Virginia's seaside communities are confronting this reality at a rate 40 percent faster than the global average. In fall 2019, Prof. Gary Hilderbrand @gary.hilderbrand @reedhilderbrand and students examined this unique setting in the studio "Adrift and Indeterminate: Designing for Perpetual Migration on Virginia’s Eastern Shore." Watch the full faculty mini-course at youtube.com/TheHarvardGSD⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
This important work would not be possible without the generosity of our alumni and friends. Your gift provides immediate support to the future of design education. Give today at 🔗hgsd.us/giving20⁣⁣
--⁣⁣
#HarvardGSD #LandscapeArchitecture #ClimateChange

node.title: Learning in action 🎥 Adrift and Indeterminate

node.text:
In their spring 2020 studio @gsdmasstimber, Profs. Jennifer Bonner @jbonn90057 and Hanif Kara @hanif.kara @akt_ii with TA/TF Nelson Byun @nelsonbyun invited students to explore the relationship between architecture and structural engineering—a dynamic modeled by Bonner and Kara’s own longtime collaboration. Following a visit to Sweden, students returned to Cambridge—and later, to Zoom—to speculate how cross-laminated timber (CLT) might be the pathway for wood to recapture the American architectural imagination. Watch the full faculty mini-course at youtube.com/TheHarvardGSD⁣⁣
 ⁣⁣
This important work would not be possible without the generosity of our alumni and friends. Your gift provides immediate support to the future of design education. Give today at 🔗hgsd.us/giving20⁣
--⁣
#HarvardGSD #Architecture #CrossLaminatedTimber

node.title: Learning in action 🎥  Mass Timber and the Scandanavian Effect

Edgar Rodriguez @edgararl (MArch '20) describes his final project for the option studio "Mass Timber and the Scandinavian Effect" @gsdmasstimber led by Jeniffer Bonner @jbonn90057 and Hanif Kara @hanif.kara @akt_ii, spring 2020. #GSDwip More at hgsd.us/gsdwip
--
#HarvardGSD #Architecture #CrossLaminatedTimber

node.text:
Designers and planners at the GSD are grappling with whether to fight the effects of #climatechange, or accept the inevitability of mass migration. Recent studios led by Rosetta S. Elkin, Eric Höweler @ehoweler, and Gary H. Hilderbrand @gary.hilderbrand took up the topic, exploring whether to "build back better" in coastal areas affected by flooding, drought, multi-species migration, and increasingly destructive natural disasters, or move to higher ground. In this video, they discuss design interventions and land-use strategies for some of our most vulnerable regions. #EarthDay 🌎
--
#harvardgsd #climateaction #earthday2020 Cover photograph by @zoltantombor

node.text:
This week we are sharing a look at some of the ways GSD faculty and students are participating in @labiennale's 17th installation, "How Will We Live Together?"⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Today's feature: Rahul Mehrotra @architectmehrotra, Chair of the Department of Urban Planning and Design and the John T. Dunlop Professor in Housing and Urbanization, and his practice Rahul Mehrotra Architect @rma_architects are participating in the Arsenale-sited "Co-Habitats: India" installation. Mehrotra’s 12-minute video installation, "Becoming Urban: Trajectories of Urbanization in India" presents research on India's emerging urban trajectory, as shaped by the proximity of cities to a densely populated hinterland, and as defined in the project as the urban-agrarian field. The installation hypothesizes that, in the future, low-rise and self-built typologies of informal settlements and urbanizing villages will house the majority of India's urban population, not only within large metropolitan cities but across tens of thousands of transitioning settlements. The installation suggests that, invoking the Biennale's guiding theme, living together in India's cities will require architects and designers to acknowledge and empower the lived experiences of millions of households who traverse the imagined political and ideological borders of urban-rural and formal-informal that are reinforced by planning and policy.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Learn more on our website in the article "GSD faculty participate in Venice Architecture Biennale’s 17th installation, 'How Will We Live Together?'" #LinkInBio. Text by Travis Dagenais @whytravis.⁣⁣⁣
--⁣⁣
#HarvardGSD #GSDFaculty #BiennaleArchitettura2021 #LaBiennaleDiVenezia #GSDatLaBiennaleArchitettura2021 @harvardurbandesign @harvardurbanplanning #India #Urbanism

node.text:
For the spring 2021 studio "Small Institutions," Roger Tudó Galí @rogertudogali, Josep Ricart Ulldemolins @josep_ricart_ulldemolins, and Xavier Ros Majó—three partners at HARQUITECTES @harquitectes in Sabadell, Spain—took Louis Kahn as their inspiration and asked students to identify the primordial essences of various institutions: library, museum, school, temple, town hall, market, theater, hospital, swimming pool, and courthouse. By focusing students' attention on determining and responding to the Kahnian agreement from which these institutions arose, the rituals inherent to these spaces become constitutive of their designs. In turn, this exercise illuminates how forms of communal interaction and public engagement have been lost and how they could be resuscitated. Moreover, it encourages a wholesale reconceptualization of #architecture in which the plan begins with nothing, to which only the necessary is added.⁣
⁣
"A lot of new institutions are losing the emotional conditions of architecture, becoming too functional and rational, and just working to avoid practical problems," says Tudó Galí. "We are very much about going against these preestablished ideas and the pragmatic approach to building. Instead, we try to rediscover the platonic idea of a place and its activities."⁣
⁣
Keep reading the article "Small Institutions: On rediscovering the emotional conditions of architecture" on our website #LinkInBio. Text by Charles Shafaieh @charlesshafaieh.⁣
--⁣
Images from Alexis Boivin's @monsieurboivin (MArch ‘22) design for a library. Learn more about this and other proposals at the #LinkInBio.⁣
--⁣
#HarvardGSD #GSDDesignNews #ArchitectureStudent #XavierRosMajó

Did you see @scarletbeeblossom's (MLA I '22) #GSDInstagramTakeover on @gsdadmissions this weekend? She shared highlights from her work as a Community Service Fellow this summer with the Destination Design School of Agricultural Estates. Here, Scarlet is with sheep friends at @Serenbe in Chattahoochee Hills, Georgia, where they brought local youth and families to learn about alternative strategies for community-based design.⁣
⁣
Watch the full takeover now in @gsdadmissions story highlights. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
--⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
Learn more about the GSD's Community Service Fellowship Program (CSFP) and read blog posts from current fellows at communityservicefellowships.gsd.harvard.edu⁣

node.text:
A look at "Transitioning Infrastructures for Sanitation Equity" by Soledad Patiño @solepatino_ (MAUD ‘20) — First prize winner of the LafargeHolcim Foundation for Sustainable Construction @holcim_foundation Next Generation Award, Asia Pacific. #GSDStudentWork⁣
 ⁣
Developed as part of the spring 2019 studio "Extreme Urbanism 6: Designing Sanitation Infrastructure" led by Prof. Rahul Mehrotra @architectmehrotra, Patiño's proposal aims to bring social and economic legitimacy to waterfront settlements of Mumbai through a new network of sanitation and community infrastructure. The international LafargeHolcim Awards recognize exemplary sustainable construction projects and visionary ideas from nearly five thousand submissions by applicants around the world in 2020. "The project suggests new multipurpose infrastructures," said the jury. "These give rise to new dynamics of water, waste, and energy management within the community, that offer a high potential in generating sustainable businesses and a strong basis for circular economy models." Learn more about Patiño's project at the #LinkInBio as well as in our #GSDwip IGTV video: "Soledad Patiño's fishing villages"⁣
--⁣
#HarvardGSD #GSDAlumni #UrbanDesign @harvardurbandesign #LafargeHolcim #LafargeHolcimAwards #Mumbai

node.text:
"If Earth’s biosphere is in crisis, it is a peculiar sort of crisis," writes Matthew Allen @the.matthew.allen. "To human eyes, it appears drawn out in slow motion over decades and spread almost invisibly across vast tracts of land. A difficult cognitive leap is required to grasp such a diffuse phenomenon. Landscape architects face a further complication: while disasters like hurricanes and wildfires can focus attention, our natural response begins with triage and mourning—far from the sort of visionary optimism that helps propel longer-term projects. And where does recovery figure into future decades of a warmer globe?"⁣
⁣
To understand these issues in the field of #LandscapeArchitecture, Allen spoke with three professors at the GSD who taught courses on the subject this spring: Steven Apfelbaum, an ecologist and founder of the ecological restoration firm AES; Silvia Benedito, a design critic and founder of the multi-disciplinary design firm OFICINAA; and David Moreno Mateos, an ecologist and assistant professor.⁣
⁣
Read what they had to say on our website in the article "GSD experts on a major barrier to climate crisis mitigation: 'The majority of Americans have little experience with the land and its rhythms.'" #LinkInBio ⁣
--⁣
Image: The seasonal cycles of burning, hunting, and harvesting practiced by the Dakota tribal communities to care for their relatives, their nonhuman relations, and the lands of Mni Sota Makoce. By Julia Rice @juliahelenrice (MLA '22) for the course "The Anatomy of (Wild)fire, a Design Quest?" led by Benedito.⁣
--⁣
#HarvardGSD @gsd_mla #ClimateChange #Ecology #DesignNews #LandscapeArchitectureStudent

node.text:
Aryan Khalighy @aryankhalighy (MArch '21) recently shared a look back at his designs for the spring 2020 option studio "Mass Timber and the Scandinavian Effect." Visit Aryan's profile for more process and final photos. ⁣
⁣
Led by Jennifer Bonner @jbonn90057 and Hanif Kara @hanif.kara with TA Nelson Byun @nelsonbyun, the studio challenged students to design a single family house and mid-rise tower out of 9-by-50-foot cross-laminated timber (CLT) blanks (large structural sheets). Browse even more student work from the course @gsdmasstimber.⁣⁣
--⁣
#HarvardGSD #Architecture #ArchitectureStudent #ArchitecturalModel #CrossLaminatedTimber

node.text:
"Cripping Architecture" by Shaina Yang @shaina_yang (MArch I '21) — Recipient of the 2021 James Templeton Kelley Prize, MArch I and the Clifford Wong Prize in Housing Design. Faculty Advisor: Preston Scott Cohen @prestonscottcohen.⁣ #GSDStudentWork #HarvardGSD21⁣
⁣
"What does architecture designed for a completely different archetype of body look like? The thesis reimagines an architectural world so tailored to native use by the wheelchairing body—to the point where it might make the able-bodied feel discomfort, despite their being technically able to 'access' it—that issues far beyond the limited purview of code come to the fore. Architectural form, motivated by the ramp, becomes a tool: for empathy, for liberation, for dialogue, for wonder." Learn more about this and other prize-winning projects by visiting our 2021 Virtual Commencement Exhibition #LinkInBio⁣
--⁣
[Image 2 Video Description:⁣⁣⁣ Rendering of a bedroom with a man using a wheelchair moving from the window to the bed while a woman using a wheelchair can be seen through an open door going down a ramp outside.]
--⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
#HarvardGSD #Architecture #ArchitectureStudent #CliffordWongPrize

node.text:
Get ready for #TokyoOlympics by looking back at drawings of the two national gymnasiums built for the Tokyo Olympic Games of 1964. Part of The Kenzo Tange Archive [丹下健三アーカイブ], Gift of Mrs. Takako Tange, 2011. Yoyogi Gymnasium (Tokyo). Frances Loeb Library, Harvard University Graduate School of Design.⁣⁣
 ⁣⁣
Designed by Kenzō Tange (1913-200), the larger gymnasium’s roof is comprised of main suspended cables anchored to the ground and raised by two concrete pillars; secondary cables hang from the main cables and are tied to two reinforced concrete arch-like structures (bow-shaped in plan). The second gymnasium has a single column, shown in detail in image four.⁣
⁣
Tange was among the most influential architects of postwar Japan. His work incorporates international modern aesthetics with traditional Japanese design. In 1987, he was awarded the @pritzkerarchitectureprize in recognition of his architecture. The Kenzō Tange Archive is comprised of architectural drawings, models, a few manuscripts, and print publications from the professional practice of Tange. Browse the archive online at hgsd.us/tangearchive #LinkInBio⁣⁣
--⁣⁣
#HarvardGSD #FrancesLoebLibrary #GSDSpecialCollections #KenzōTange #KenzoTange #KenzōTangeArchive #Architecture #ArchitecturalDrawing #Olympics #Tokyo2020 #HarvardLibrary #TBT #HarvardGSDTBT @harvard_library @olympics
